column1: Plastics are a wide range of synthetic or semi-synthetic organic compounds that are malleable and so can be molded into solid objects.
Plasticity is the general property of all materials which can deform irreversibly without breaking but
column2: in the class of moldable polymers
column3: this occurs to such a degree that their actual name derives from this specific ability.

column1: Most plastics contain organic polymers. The vast majority of these polymers are formed from chains of carbon atoms
column2: 'pure' or with the addition of: oxygen
column3: nitrogen
column4: or sulfur. The chains comprise many repeat units
column5: formed from monomers. Each polymer chain will have several thousand repeating units.

column1: The backbone is the part of the chain that is on the "main path"
column2: linking together a large number of repeat units.

column1: To customize the properties of a plastic
column2: different molecular groups "hang" from this backbone. These pendant units are usually "hung" on the monomers
column3: before the monomers themselves are linked together to form the polymer chain.  It is the structure of these side chains that influences the properties of the polymer.

column1: The molecular structure of the repeating unit can be fine tuned to influence specific properties of the polymer.

column15: and figurines. Treated cattle horns were used as windows for lanterns in the Middle Ages.  Materials that mimicked the properties of horns were developed by treating milk-proteins (casein) with lye.

column1: Parkesine (nitrocellulose) is considered the first man-made plastic. The plastic material was patented by Alexander Parkes
column2: in Birmingham
column3: England in 1856.  It was unveiled at the 1862 Great International Exhibition in London. Parkesine won a bronze medal at the 1862 World's fair in London. Parkesine was made from cellulose (the major component of plant cell walls) treated with nitric acid as a solvent. The output of the process (commonly known as cellulose nitrate or pyroxilin) could be dissolved in alcohol and hardened into a transparent and elastic material that could be molded when heated. By incorporating pigments into the product
column4: it could be made to resemble ivory.

The final result was unsuitable for the original purpose. In 1893

column2: the COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating effect on the fossil fuel and petrochemical industry. Natural gas prices have dropped so low that gas producers were burning if off on-site (not being worth the cost to transport it to cracking facilities). In addition
column3: bans on single-use consumer plastic (in China
column4: the European Union
column5: Canada
column6: and many countries in Africa)
column7: and bans on plastic bags (in several states in the USA) has reduced demand for plastics considerably. Many cracking facilities in the USA have been suspended. The petrochemical industry has been trying to save itself by attempting to rapidly expand demand for plastic products worldwide (i.e. through pushbacks on plastic bans and by increasing the number of products wrapped in plastic in countries where plastic use is not already as widespread (i.e. developing nations)).

column1: Most plastics are durable and degrade very slowly
column2: as their chemical structure renders them resistant to many natural processes of degradation. There are differing estimates of how much plastic waste has been produced in the last century. By one estimate
column3: one billion tons of plastic waste have been discarded since the 1950s. Others estimate a cumulative human production of 8.3 billion tons of plastic of which 6.3 billion tons is waste
column4: with a recycling rate of only 9%. Much of this material may persist for centuries or longer
column5: given the demonstrated persistence of structurally similar natural materials such as amber.

Polymer degradation takes much longer as a result of saline environments and the cooling effect of the sea. These factors contribute to the persistence of plastic debris in certain environments. Recent studies have shown that plastics in the ocean decompose faster than was once thought

column4: rain

column17: wood burning bans while planting "as many trees as possible

column2: commonly called "vinyl") incorporates chlorine atoms.  The C-Cl bonds in the backbone are hydrophobic and resist oxidation (and burning). PVC is stiff
column3: strong
column4: heat and weather resistant
column5: properties that recommend its use in devices for plumbing
column6: gutters
column8: enclosures for computers and other electronics gear. PVC can also be softened with chemical processing
column9: and in this form it is now used for shrink-wrap

column1: All PVC polymers are degraded by heat and light. When this happens
column2: hydrogen chloride is released into the atmosphere and oxidation of the compound occurs. Because hydrogen chloride readily combines with water vapor in the air to form hydrochloric acid
column3: polyvinyl chloride is not recommended for long-term archival storage of silver
column4: photographic film or paper (mylar is preferable).

column1: The plastics industry was revolutionized in the 1930s with the announcement of polyamide (PA)
column2: far better known by its trade name nylon. Nylon was the first purely synthetic fiber
column3: introduced by DuPont Corporation at the 1939 World's Fair in New York City.

column2: DuPont had begun a secret development project designated Fiber66
column3: under the direction of Harvard chemist Wallace Carothers and chemistry department director Elmer Keiser Bolton. Carothers had been hired to perform pure research
column4: and he worked to understand the new materials' molecular structure and physical properties. He took some of the first steps in the molecular design of the materials.

column1: His work led to the discovery of synthetic nylon fiber
column2: which was very strong but also very flexible. The first application was for bristles for toothbrushes. However
column3: Du Pont's real target was silk
column4: particularly silk stockings. Carothers and his team synthesized a number of different polyamides including polyamide 6.6 and 4.6
column5: as well as polyesters.

column1: It took DuPont twelve years and US$27 million to refine nylon
column2: and to synthesize and develop the industrial processes for bulk manufacture. With such a major investment
column3: it was no surprise that Du Pont spared little expense to promote nylon after its introduction
column4: creating a public sensation
column5: or "nylon mania".

column1: Nylon mania came to an abrupt stop at the end of 1941 when the US entered World War II. The production capacity that had been built up to produce nylon stockings
column2: or just nylons
column3: for American women was taken over to manufacture vast numbers of parachutes for fliers and paratroopers. After the war ended
column4: DuPont went back to selling nylon to the public
column5: engaging in another promotional campaign in 1946 that resulted in an even bigger craze
column6: triggering the so-called nylon riots.

column2: polyamides 6
column5: and 12 have been developed based on monomers which are ring compounds; e.g. caprolactam. Nylon 66 is a material manufactured by condensation polymerization.

column2: and not just for use in fabrics. In its bulk form it is very wear resistant
column3: particularly if oil-impregnated
column4: and so is used to build gears
column5: plain bearings
column6: valve seats
column7: seals and because of good heat-resistance
column8: increasingly for under-the-hood applications in cars

column2: also known as acrylic or acrylic glass as well as by the trade names Plexiglas
column3: Acrylite
column4: Lucite
column5: and Perspex among several others (see below)
column6: is a transparent thermoplastic often used in sheet form as a lightweight or shatter-resistant alternative to glass.  The same material can be utilised as a casting resin
column8: and has many other uses.

column1: Natural rubber is an elastomer (an elastic hydrocarbon polymer) that originally was derived from latex
column2: a milky colloidal suspension found in specialised vessels in some plants. It is useful directly in this form (indeed
column3: the first appearance of rubber in Europe was cloth waterproofed with unvulcanized latex from Brazil). However
column5: Charles Goodyear invented vulcanized rubber; a form of natural rubber heated with sulfur (and a few other chemicals)
column6: forming cross-links between polymer chains (vulcanization)

column2: Nelson Goodyear added fillers to natural rubber materials to form ebonite.

column1: The first fully synthetic rubber was synthesized by Sergei Lebedev in 1910. In World War II
column2: supply blockades of natural rubber from South East Asia caused a boom in development of synthetic rubber
column3: notably styrene-butadiene rubber. In 1941
column4: annual production of synthetic rubber in the U.S. was only 231 tonnes which increased to 840
column5: 000 tonnes in 1945. In the space race and nuclear arms race
column6: Caltech researchers experimented with using synthetic rubbers for solid fuel for rockets. Ultimately
column7: all large military rockets and missiles would use synthetic rubber based solid fuels
column8: and they would also play a significant part in the civilian space effort.
